title: Top Supplement Ingredients for High Blood Pressure
author: Kayla Robinson; BKin; RHN
description: High blood pressure or hypertension occurs when the blood pressure in your arteries increases to unhealthy levels.
cleaned_text: Hypertension, or high blood pressure, is a significant and growing global health concern. Accounting for 7.5 million deaths annually ( [17](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5733954/)), hypertension is the leading risk factor for heart disease, stroke, and premature death. ( [6](https://bmjopen.bmj.com/content/3/8/e003423#ref-1)) The number of individuals with hypertension is expected to increase in the coming years and is predicted to reach 1.56 billion adults worldwide by 2025. ( [17](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5733954/)) What is hypertension? Hypertension is a common condition in which blood flows through blood vessels and arteries with greater than normal pressure. ( [12](https://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health-topics/high-blood-pressure)) While normal blood pressure is defined as systolic blood pressure less than 120 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure less than 80 mm Hg ( [2](https://www.omicsonline.org/open-access/hypertension-pathophysiology-and-treatment-2155-9562-5-1000250.php?aid=35433)) ( [17](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5733954/)), hypertension is characterized by systolic blood pressure greater than 130 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure greater than 80 mmHg. The American Heart Association outlines the following blood pressure ranges: - Normal blood pressure: systolic blood pressure less than 120 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure less than 80 mmHg - Elevated blood pressure: systolic blood pressure greater than 120 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure less than 80 mmHg - Stage 1 Hypertension: systolic blood pressure greater than 130 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure greater than 80 mmHg - Stage 2 Hypertension: systolic blood pressure greater than 140 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure greater than 90 mmHg - Hypertensive Crisis: systolic blood pressure greater than 180 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure greater than 120 mmHg ( [19](https://www.heart.org/en/health-topics/high-blood-pressure/understanding-blood-pressure-readings)) Causes and risk factors Several causes and risk factors have been identified in the development of hypertension, including: - Age: the risk of developing hypertension increases with age - Certain medical conditions such as chronic kidney disease, [obesity](https://fullscript.com/blog/obesity), sleep apnea, thyroid conditions, and certain tumors - Certain medications such as contraceptive pills and cold-relief medications - Excess alcohol intake - Excess dietary intake of [sodium](https://fullscript.com/blog/sodium) - Family history/genetic predisposition - Gender: men are more likely to develop high blood pressure before age 55, while women are at an increased risk after 55 - Race: hypertension is more common in African American individuals compared to white, Hispanic, and Asian individuals - Sedentary lifestyle - Urban living (compared to rural) ( [17](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5733954/))( [12](https://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health-topics/high-blood-pressure)) Signs, symptoms, and complications Hypertension is known as the "silent killer" because the condition is most often asymptomatic until the occurrence of a severe medical event such as a heart attack or stroke. ( [17](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5733954/)) In some cases, signs of high blood pressure include lightheadedness, fainting episodes, vertigo, or altered vision, ( [17](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5733954/)) Complications associated with high blood pressure include: - Aneurysms - Heart failure - Myocardial infarction - Peripheral artery disease - Renal impairment - Stroke - Vascular dementia - Visual impairment and retinal hemorrhage ( [12](https://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health-topics/high-blood-pressure)) ( [17](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5733954/)) Ingredients for blood pressure support Hypertension and its complications are largely preventable with lifestyle and [dietary](https://fullscript.com/blog/heart-health-foods) modifications. ( [6](https://bmjopen.bmj.com/content/3/8/e003423#ref-1)) Studies have shown that reductions as little as 10mmHg systolic or 5 mm Hg diastolic blood pressure decreased the risk of cardiovascular-related death and stroke by approximately 25% and 40%, respectively. ( [7](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19454737)) Magnesium Among the most abundant minerals in the body, magnesium plays an integral role in many body functions, including insulin metabolism, energy production, nerve transmission, cardiac excitability, and blood pressure regulation. ( [5](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5420140/)) A number of underlying mechanisms are believed to be involved in the hypotensive effects of magnesium. These mechanisms include: - Enhanced effect of antihypertensive medication - Increased nitric oxide levels - Increased secretion of endothelial prostaglandin I2 - Interaction with calcium in the body - Reduced peripheral vascular resistance ( [3](https://academic.oup.com/ajcn/article/106/3/921/4822367)) Supplemental magnesium has been shown to both systolic and diastolic blood pressure. ( [3](https://academic.oup.com/ajcn/article/106/3/921/4822367))( [22](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27402922)) Further research has identified an inverse correlation between circulating magnesium and the incidence of hypertension. ( [5](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5420140/))( [20](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28927411)) Garlic sativum) [Garlic](https://fullscript.com/blog/garlic), a bulbous plant belonging to the Lillaceae family, has a long history of culinary and therapeutic uses dating back to ancient civilizations. Allicin is the primary active constituent of garlic and commonly extracted for use in supplements. Allicin is produced by the alliinase enzyme, which is activated when raw garlic is crushed or chopped. Another common form of garlic extract, aged garlic extract, is produced by storing the plant in 15-20% ethanol for longer than one and a half years. ( [1](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4103721/)) Among the most popular complementary therapies for hypertension ( [21](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25837272)), garlic demonstrates immunomodulatory and cardiovascular protective effects. ( [15](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26764326)) Garlic is regarded as a safe and effective supplement for improving hypertension. ( [9](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5021928/)) L-arginine has been shown to lower blood pressure in individuals with mild to moderate hypertension. ( [10](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27817128)) In one study, L-arginine lowered diastolic blood pressure in individuals with gestational hypertension compared to a placebo. ( [4](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23435582)) The bottom line While hypertension is a widespread and serious condition, it is also largely preventable. A protocol using natural supplements can be used therapeutically on its own or as an adjunct to existing high blood pressure treatment plan. If you're a patient, we recommend speaking with your healthcare provider to learn whether these supplements are right for your wellness plan.
